Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Costs of Plasticity in Plant Defense: Sexual and Asexual Fitness Across Years
Award.AbstractNarration:
One characteristic of invasive weeds that may contribute to their success is their ability to actively respond to herbivores. Understanding the spread of weeds therefore requires studying how these responses, called "induced defenses", may evolve. While many invasive weeds live for many years and can reproduce asexually through underground stems, previous studies of defense evolution have only measured sexual reproduction (seed set) over one year. This project examines the evolution of induced defenses in the weed Solanum carolinense by using genetic analysis to measure both sexual and asexual reproduction. Sexual reproduction and defenses have already been measured in an ongoing field experiment over one year; re-sprouts from this experiment will be identified using microsatellite DNA analysis to quantify reproduction in a second year. The relationship between defenses and combined reproduction will indicate how induced defenses are expected to evolve in natural populations.

This project will address how herbivores affect the evolution and asexual spread of a noxious weed that is also a host for several economically important insect pests, including the Colorado potato beetle. Better understanding of how weeds succeed is relevant to developing better management of weeds and invasive species. Additionally, this project will develop genetic markers for future studies and provide undergraduate research training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phenotypic plasticity is the ability of organisms to respond to environmental change. Plasticity benefits organisms that live in variable environments, allowing them to optimally respond to a variety of conditions. Human impacts on natural ecosystems (e.g., climate change and habitat fragmentation) often increase environmental variability. Phenotypic plasticity may thus become increasingly important for the persistence of animal and plant populations.  Understanding what promotes or limits the evolution of plasticity can help explain how organisms adapt (or not) to environmental change. However, despite decades of evolutionary theory on the subject, we still know surprisingly little about how phenotypic plasticity evolves in natural populations.

    Our project investigated the evolution of phenotypic plasticity in the defense response of plants to their insect herbivores. Many plants have the ability to respond to insect damage by increasing the production of chemical and mechanical defenses.  This plasticity in defense is termed “induced defense”.  Plants can also respond to damage by allocating resources to growth and reproduction to maintain fitness after damage; this is termed “tolerance”.  Induced defenses and tolerance are model examples of phenotypic plasticity and much is known about their ecological effects on insect herbivores; however, little is understood about how these plasticities evolve. In particular, it is often assumed that pathways required for plasticity are costly to maintain, but there are very few demonstrations of costs of plasticity in these traits. Additionally, most experimental work on induced defenses and tolerance has focused on perennial plants. In contrast, costs of plasticity have been examined almost exclusively in annual plants and, before our project, no study had measured costs of plasticity in perennial plants in terms of asexual reproduction or across growing seasons. As a result, we know little about the evolution of defensive plasticity in perennial plants, even though perennial plants are both economically and ecologically important.

    Using field experiments, we examined the evolution of induced defenses in the clonal perennial weed Solanum carolinense. We planted 16 clonal lines of this plant in environments with ambient and reduced densities of insect herbivores. We measured each clonal line’s production of several defenses (tolerance, proteinase inhibitors, prickles, leaf toughness, and trichomes) in the damaged and undamaged state. We then quantified the effect of defense expression on sexual and asexual reproduction in each herbivore environment. This allowed us to determine whether plasticity in defense is favored across herbivore environments, or whether, accounting for potential benefits of plasticity, the ability to increase defenses after herbivory is reproductively costly. Using microsatellite analysis to genotype clonal recruits, we were able to measure plant reproduction over two growing seasons. In doing so, our study is the first to comprehensively measure both the fitness benefits of induced defenses and potential limits on the evolution of these traits in a natural field setting.

    We found that within one growing season, though plants received significantly more damage when herbivores were present, plasticity was not favored in any plant defense. Instead, reduced production of defense was favored in all environments, so the ability to increase defenses after damage did not lead to increased reproduction. While plasticity was not beneficial to plant fitness, it was not generally costly either.
